pages.text: Leptolepis was a genus of small, planktivorous, basal teleost (i.e. bony) fish that lived during the Lower to Middle Jurassic. The distribution of this superficially herring-like fish seems to have been more or less global, with most of the fossils coming from the northern hemisphere, but a few also being found in Australia.

It was also found in both marine and freshwater ecosystems, including at the famous Morrison Formation. For a long time, Leptolepis was used as a wastebasket taxon, until Swedish ichthyologist Orvar Nybelin revised the genus in 1974, narrowing it down to seven recognized species. Mass graves of Leptolepis suggest that it lived in large schools.
